newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks dazzle as investors charge in.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks dazzle as investors charge in.

text.p: Mexican stocks soared to breathtaking heights Thursday as bullish investors crowned the country the new gem among emerging markets.
"It's almost the flip side of what recently happened in Brazil. Instead of panic selling you've got panic buying," said Todd Edwards, Latin American investment strategist at the Latinvest brokerage.
Since landmark midterm elections July 6, the Mexican stock market has gotten a new lease on life, buoyed by the recovering economy and the best signs of widespread business profits in years.

With liquidity high as investors look for a safe haven from currency woes in Asia, and with local rival Brazil considered overbought, Mexico has become the emerging market of choice in the cutthroat race for investment, experts said.

Early Thursday, Mexico's IPC index barely paused as it burst through the 5,000-point barrier for the first time ever. By midafternoon it had clocked up gains of 150.67 points, or 3.03 percent, to reach a new record of 5,124.90.
The market pared earlier gains at the close Thursday, but was still up 93.60 points at a record 5,067.83. These gains came following the highest rise ever in terms of points on Wednesday.
Underpinning confidence was a rock-solid peso that appears to have shed much of the stigma left over from a disastrous devaluation in 1994.

Democracy has also helped. In congressional elections earlier this month, opposition parties broke the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party's 68-year lock on the lower house of Congress, which analysts said cut the risk of political storms.
"We've washed out of the elections and the mid-month turbulence on Brazil, so we're off to the races again," said Geoffrey Dennis, emerging markets startegist at HSBC-James Capel.
"The feeling is upward earnings momentum is here, the economy is improving on the margin and you have a vote of confidence in the peso."
For Vinod Seghal, head of equity research at the Societe General brokerage, Mexico may have become a logical venue for emerging market funds.
"You take liquidity away from Asia and off the major markets, and it has to go to Brazil or Mexico, and there is a feeling that Brazil may have played out," he said.
Seghal also said the recent slew of second-quarter earnings reports had helped propel gains.
"At last there are signs of growth in consumption, which is what we've all been waiting for for two years -- previously it was all export-based," he said.
Looking ahead, the stockwatchers said the market still had strong upside potential, but said healthy profit-taking could intervene along the way.
"What's happening now is a function of liquidity ... and people should not underestimate what liquidity can do," Seghal said. "It's hard to make a bearish case right now."
Dennis said he would not recommend heavy profit-taking until the IPC headed toward a mid-1998 target of 5,600 points, although he said he may have to bring that target forward.
The main stumbling block for the market, the analysts said, was a strong peso that could eat into earnings posted by exporting companies for the third quarter in October.
Dennis said that, although investors may become nervous that the peso could slip, the risk of a free fall was reduced.
"The maximum adjustment in the peso will be 8 percent, and that's about a day's worth in Asian markets recently," he said.
